Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: P2C2--Paleoclimate and Cultural Change in Mesoamerica: Testing the Hypothesis of ENSO Forcing of Late Holocene Rainfall Variability
Award.AbstractNarration:
The researchers aim to develop several high-resolution (~2 to 5 year), time-overlapping and replicated delta oxygen-18 isotope records over the past five millennia from uranium series dated stalagmites collected in an El Nino-Southern Oscillation (ENSO) sensitive region of southwestern Mexico. The goal of the project is to test the hypothesis that southern Mexico experienced prolonged wet conditions during the Medieval Climatic Anomaly (MCA) that was coincident with a more La Ni√±a-like state of low sea surface temperatures in the eastern Pacific Ocean.

The primary broader impacts involve the education of a doctoral student and the development of English and Spanish guides to cave science for interested members of the public in the U.S. and in Mexico. Also, the science results could have broad application to many areas in the physical and social sciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this research project, our team accomplished the major goal to develop a high resolution rainfall proxy record for the Mesoamerican monsoon from cave stalagmites. The rainfall reconstruction was based on a calibration of stalagmite oxygen isotope values for the modern era to rainfall amount in central and  southwestern Mexico, and this quantitative calibration was extended to 2200 yr BP at a temporal resolution of 2 to 4 years. The rainfall reconstruction permitted a quantitative rainfall amount record for central Mexico, which could be compared to cultural changes in the Basin of Mexico and elsewhere. Specifically, we showed that the fall of the great Mesoamerican  city ofTeotihuacan around 550 CE followed several centuries of drying  conditions. Because the city relied on spring-fed irrigation agriculture to grow crops, we hypothesized that the centennial scale trend to drying conditions would have added a stressor to the Teotihuacano civilization. The results of this study were published in a high-profile journal in the journal "Geology" in 2012, and other manuscripts are in press and in preparation.

In addition to the last two millennia, we published a high-profile paper on the longer-term evolution of the Mesoamerican Monsoon over the last 22,000 years in 2013 in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences. This paper was based on data from other stalagmites collected from the same cave in Mexico, Juxtlahuaca Cave, as well as one other nearby cave called Cueva del Diablo (published in Quaternary Research in 2011). The results showed that the monsoon collapsed during Heinrich event 1 (from 17,000 to 15,000 years before present) when northern hemisphere ice sheets rapidly collapsed and discharged ice bergs into the North Atlantic Ocean, disrupting ocean circulation, and the Younger Dryas (12,500 to 11,000 yr BP), and that the monsoon was strongest during the early Holocene with a trend to drying conditions to the present. The characteristics of the oxygen isotope  curve for the last 22,000 years document that the forcings on the  Mesoamerican monsoon are orbital forcing of the monsoon and ocean circulation-forced disruptions of atmospheric circulation associated with abrupt climate events.
